question: The Award costs include 'Administrative expenses: ₹15,000.' What do administrative expenses in arbitration cover? <case_id:case_007, folder_id:ARB/2024/1007>
golden_answers: Administrative expenses typically include: (1) Hearing venue charges, (2) Stenographer/transcription costs, (3) Communication and courier expenses, (4) Document copying and binding, (5) Filing and registration fees, (6) Secretarial support, (7) Miscellaneous disbursements. For a 4-5 month arbitration, ₹15,000 administrative costs are reasonable.

question: The recovery timeline shows the last interaction before legal action was 'Phone switched off' on 20-08-2023. How should unresponsive borrowers be handled? <case_id:case_007, folder_id:ARB/2024/1007>
golden_answers: When borrowers become unresponsive: (1) Immediate field visit to verify status, (2) Employer/business verification, (3) Alternate contact attempts, (4) Written notice to registered address, (5) Legal escalation if pattern confirms evasion vs. genuine communication breakdown. The key is distinguishing between 'can't pay and hiding' vs. 'can't pay and overwhelmed'—different situations warrant different approaches.

question: The Award mentions the claimant can 'attach and sell any assets.' Does this include assets essential for basic livelihood? <case_id:case_007, folder_id:ARB/2024/1007>
golden_answers: CPC exempts certain assets from attachment: (1) Necessary wearing apparel, (2) Tools of artisans, (3) Books of account, (4) One month's provisions, (5) Agricultural implements, (6) Stipend/wages to certain extent. A few personal items are protected. However, business equipment, luxury items, and substantial assets are attachable. Courts balance recovery rights with basic subsistence protection.

question: The case file shows multiple mixed content (bakery references, different borrowers). What quality control failed? <case_id:case_007, folder_id:ARB/2024/1007>
golden_answers: Quality failures include: (1) Template-based document generation without proper customization, (2) Copy-paste errors from similar cases, (3) Lack of document review before filing, (4) No case-specific checklist verification, (5) Inadequate training on document preparation. Systematic quality controls—file naming conventions, mandatory review checklists, document headers—would prevent such mixing.

question: The EMI amount was ₹11,678/month. The borrower's stated income was ₹65,000/month. The EMI-to-income ratio was 18%. Is this sustainable? <case_id:case_007, folder_id:ARB/2024/1007>
golden_answers: An 18% EMI ratio is well within sustainable limits (typically 30-40% maximum for total EMIs). This suggests the loan was appropriately sized for stated income. The default occurred not due to over-leveraging but due to income disappearance when the business closed. The original underwriting appears sound; the business failure was the problem.

question: The Award directs payment of ₹6,52,863 within 30 days. If the borrower cannot pay, what are her options? <case_id:case_007, folder_id:ARB/2024/1007>
golden_answers: Options include: (1) Propose installment arrangement to the claimant, (2) Offer settlement at reduced amount, (3) Voluntarily surrender assets for partial satisfaction, (4) Apply under Section 34 to challenge award (if grounds exist), (5) Negotiate with family for support, (6) Accept execution and cooperate with attachment. Ignoring the award leads to forced execution with additional costs.
